pytomography.utils#

This module contains utility functions used in the other modules of PyTomography

Submodules#

  • pytomography.utils.helper_functions

Package Contents#

Functions#

rev_cumsum(x)

Reverse cumulative sum along the first axis of a tensor of shape [batch_size, Lx, Ly, Lz].

rotate_detector_z(x, angles[, mode, negative])

Returns an object tensor in a rotated reference frame such that the scanner is located at the +x axis. Note that the scanner angle $eta$ is related to $phi$ (azimuthal angle) by $phi = 3pi/2 - eta$.

get_distance(Lx, r, dx)

Given the radial distance to center of object space from the scanner, computes the distance

compute_pad_size(width)

Computes the pad width required such that subsequent rotation retains the entire image

pad_image(image[, mode, value])

Pads an image along the Lr axis

pad_object(object[, mode])

Pads object tensors by enough pixels in the xy plane so that subsequent rotations don't crop out any of the object

unpad_image(image)

Unpads the image back to original Lr dimensions

unpad_object(object)

Unpads a padded object tensor in the xy plane back to its original dimensions

pad_object_z(object, pad_size[, mode])

Pads an object tensor along z. Useful for PSF modeling

unpad_object_z(object, pad_size)

Unpads an object along the z dimension

get_object_nearest_neighbour(object, shifts)

get_blank_below_above(image)

Obtains the number of blank z-slices at the sup (blank_above) and inf (blank_below) of the projection data. This method is entirely empircal, and looks for z slices where there are zero detected counts.

bilinear_transform(arr, a1, b1, a2, b2)

Converts an array of Hounsfield Units into linear attenuation coefficient using the bilinear transformation \(f(x)=a_1x+b_1\) for positive \(x\) and \(f(x)=a_2x+b_2\) for negative \(x\).
pytomography.utils.rev_cumsum(x)[source]#

Reverse cumulative sum along the first axis of a tensor of shape [batch_size, Lx, Ly, Lz]. since this is used with CT correction, the initial voxel only contributes 1/2.

Parameters:

x (torch.tensor[batch_size,Lx,Ly,Lz]) â€“ Tensor to be summed

Returns:

The cumulatively summed tensor.

Return type:

torch.tensor[batch_size, Lx, Ly, Lz]

pytomography.utils.rotate_detector_z(x, angles, mode='bilinear', negative=False)[source]#

Returns an object tensor in a rotated reference frame such that the scanner is located at the +x axis. Note that the scanner angle $eta$ is related to $phi$ (azimuthal angle) by $phi = 3pi/2 - eta$.

Parameters:

  • x (torch.tensor[batch_size, Lx, Ly, Lz]) â€“ Tensor aligned with cartesian coordinate system specified

  • manual. (by the) â€“

  • angles (torch.Tensor) â€“ The angles $eta$ where the scanner is located for each element in the batch x.

  • mode (str, optional) â€“ Method of interpolation used to get rotated image. Defaults to bilinear.

  • negative (bool, optional) â€“ If True, applies an inverse rotation. In this case, the tensor

  • $eta$ (x is an object in a coordinate system aligned with) â€“

  • the (and the function rotates) â€“

  • particular (x back to the original cartesian coordinate system specified by the users manual. In) â€“

  • one (if) â€“

  • negative=False (uses this function on a tensor with) â€“

  • returned (then applies this function to that) â€“

  • negative=True (tensor with) â€“

  • False. (it should return the same tensor. Defaults to) â€“

Returns:

Rotated tensor.

Return type:

torch.tensor[batch_size, Lx, Ly, Lz]

pytomography.utils.get_distance(Lx, r, dx)[source]#
Given the radial distance to center of object space from the scanner, computes the distance

between each parallel plane (i.e. (y-z plane)) and a detector located at +x. This function is used for point spread function (PSF) blurring where the amount of blurring depends on thedistance from the detector.

Parameters:

  • Lx (int) â€“ The number of y-z planes to compute the distance of

  • r (float) â€“ The radial distance between the central y-z plane and the detector at +x.

  • dx (float) â€“ The spacing between y-z planes in Euclidean distance.

Returns:

An array of distances for each y-z plane to the detector.

Return type:

np.array[Lx]

pytomography.utils.compute_pad_size(width)[source]#

Computes the pad width required such that subsequent rotation retains the entire image

Parameters:

width (int) â€“ width of the corresponding axis (i.e. number of elements in the dimension)

Returns:

the number of pixels by which the axis needs to be padded on each side

Return type:

int

Parameters:

  • mode (str, optional) â€“ Padding mode to use. Defaults to â€˜constantâ€™.

  • value (float, optional) â€“ If padding mode is constant, fill with this value. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

Padded image tensor.

Return type:

pytomography.utils.pad_object_z(object, pad_size, mode='constant')[source]#

pytomography.utils.get_blank_below_above(image)[source]#

Obtains the number of blank z-slices at the sup (blank_above) and inf (blank_below) of the projection data. This method is entirely empircal, and looks for z slices where there are zero detected counts.

Parameters:

image (torch.tensor) â€“ Image data from a scanner

Returns:

A tuple of two elements corresponding to the number of blank slices at the inf, and the number of blank slices at the sup.

Return type:

Sequence[int]

pytomography.utils.bilinear_transform(arr, a1, b1, a2, b2)[source]#

Converts an array of Hounsfield Units into linear attenuation coefficient using the bilinear transformation \(f(x)=a_1x+b_1\) for positive \(x\) and \(f(x)=a_2x+b_2\) for negative \(x\).

Parameters:

  • arr (np.array) â€“ Array to be transformed using bilinear transformation

  • a1 (float) â€“ Bilinear slope for negative input values

  • b1 (float) â€“ Bilinear intercept for negative input values

  • a2 (float) â€“ Bilinear slope for positive input values

  • b2 (float) â€“ Bilinear intercept for positive input values

Returns:

Transformed array.

Return type:

np.array
